news_summary: NASA's Artemis II mission advances as its mega Moon rocket successfully arrives at the launch pad, marking a significant milestone in lunar exploration.
news_summary_fr: La mission Artemis II de la NASA progresse alors que sa méga-fusée lunaire arrive avec succès sur la rampe de lancement, marquant une étape importante dans l'exploration lunaire.
news_summary_es: La misión Artemis II de la NASA avanza con éxito tras la llegada de su mega cohete lunar a la plataforma de lanzamiento, lo que supone un hito importante en la exploración lunar.

articles.title: Nasa's mega Moon rocket arrives at launch pad for Artemis II mission
articles.summary: Final preparations now get underway for the first crewed mission to the Moon in more than 50 years.
articles.content:
Nasa's mega Moon rocket arrives at launch pad for Artemis II mission

3 hours ago Share Save Rebecca Morelle, Alison Francis and Kevin Church Science team Share Save

Watch: Timelapse shows Nasa rocket's 12-hour journey to launch pad

Nasa's mega rocket has been moved to the launch pad in Cape Canaveral, Florida, as the final preparations get underway for the first crewed mission to the Moon in more than 50 years. Over almost 12 hours, the 98m-tall Space Launch System was carried vertically from the Vehicle Assembly Building on the 4-mile (6.5km) journey to the pad. Now it is in position, the final tests, checks - and a dress rehearsal - will take place, before the go-ahead is given for the 10-day Artemis II mission that will see four astronauts travel around the Moon. Nasa says the earliest the rocket can blast off is 6 February, but there are also more launch windows later that month, as well as in March and April.

Reuters The Space Launch System (SLS) rocket that will fly the Artemis II mission to the Moon

The rocket began moving at 07:04 local time (12:04 GMT) and arrived at Launch Pad 39B at the Kennedy Space Center at 18:41 local time (23:42 GMT). The rocket was carried by a huge machine called a crawler-transporter, travelling at a top speed of 0.82 mph (1.3 km/h) as it trundled along. Live coverage captured the slow-moving spectacle. Nasa said the rocket will be prepared over the next few days for what it calls a "wet dress rehearsal" - a test for fuel operations and countdown procedures. The Artemis II crew - Nasa's Reid Wiseman, Victor Glover and Christina Koch and Canadian astronaut Jeremy Hansen - were at the Kennedy Space Center watching the rocket as it was moved. In just a few weeks, the four astronauts will be strapped into a spacecraft, perched on the top of the rocket, ready to blast off to the Moon. It will be the first crewed mission to the Moon since Apollo 17 landed on its surface in December 1972.

NASA From left to right the Artemis crew is Reid Wiseman, Victor Glover, Christina Koch and Jeremy Hansen

Nasa said the mission could take its astronauts further into space that anyone has been before. Artemis II is not scheduled to land on the Moon, but will instead lay the groundwork for a future lunar landing led by the Artemis III mission. Nasa said the launch of Artemis III will take place "no earlier than" 2027. But, experts believe 2028 is the earliest possible date. Koch said it was an amazing feeling to see the rocket. "Astronauts are the calmest people on launch day. And I think... it feels that way because we're just so ready to fulfil the mission that we came here to do, that we've trained to do," she said. Hansen said he hoped the mission would inspire the world. "The Moon is something that I've taken for granted. I've looked at it my whole life, but then you just glance at it and glance away," he said. "But now I've been staring at it a lot more, and I think others will be joining us and staring at the Moon a lot more as there will be humans flying around the far side and that is just good for humanity."

Before Artemis II heads to the Moon, the first two days of their mission will be spent in orbit around the Earth. "We're going to be going into an orbit almost right away that is 40,000 miles out - like a fifth of the way of the Moon," Koch told BBC News. "We will have the Earth out the window as a single ball, something none of us have seen in that perspective. "And then we're going to travel a quarter of a million miles away… we're going to do a lot of science and operations along the way." While they fly around the far side of the Moon, the crew will have three hours dedicated to lunar observation - to gaze, take images and to study its geology, which will help plan and prepare for a future landing at the Moon's south pole.

NASA The European Service Module provides power and propulsions and life support systems

A key part of the Orion spacecraft that the astronauts will be flying in was made in Bremen in Germany. The European Service Module, which sits behind the crew capsule, is the European Space Agency's contribution to the mission and has been built by Airbus. "The European Service Module is so important - we basically can't get to the Moon without it," says Sian Cleaver, a spacecraft engineer at Airbus. "It provides the propulsion that Orion needs to get us to the Moon." Its large solar arrays will generate all the electrical power for the craft, she adds. "We've also got these big tanks full of oxygen and nitrogen, which are mixed to make air, and also water, so that we can provide everything that the astronauts need in the crew module to keep them alive on their journey."

Kevin Church/ BBC News Sian Cleaver from Airbus says the safety of the astronauts is the top priority

Inside their cleanroom, the team is busy building more modules for future Artemis missions. Each one takes about 18 months to put together but has taken thousands of engineering hours to design. Everything on board has to work perfectly. "We've got to get those astronauts to the Moon and then back again, completely safely," says Cleaver.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant real-world event: the preparation of NASA's Artemis II mission, the first crewed lunar mission in over 50 years, which represents a major milestone in human space exploration with broad public interest and inspirational impact. It provides detailed context about the mission, the technology involved, and its significance for future lunar exploration.
articles.personality_title: NASA's Artemis II rocket reaches launch pad for first crewed Moon trip in 50 years
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – NASA is preparing for Artemis II, the first mission with astronauts to orbit the Moon since 1972. This mission will test new technology and get ready for future Moon landings.

**What happened** – The giant Space Launch System rocket was slowly moved 4 miles to its launch pad at Kennedy Space Center in Florida. This took nearly 12 hours. Now, NASA will run final tests and a full practice countdown before the mission’s planned launch as early as February 6, 2024. Four astronauts, including three from NASA and one from Canada, will fly around the Moon but not land.

**Impact** – Artemis II will send humans farther into space than ever before. The crew will orbit around the far side of the Moon, study its surface, and prepare for Artemis III, which aims to land astronauts on the Moon’s south pole. The European Space Agency helped build a key part of the spacecraft that will provide power, propulsion, and life support for the crew.

**What's next step** – After the tests and dress rehearsal, NASA will decide the exact launch date. The Artemis II mission will last about 10 days, including two days orbiting Earth before heading to the Moon. Meanwhile, engineers continue building modules for future missions that will bring humans back to the Moon’s surface.

**One-sentence takeaway** – NASA’s Artemis II mission marks a major step toward returning astronauts to the Moon by safely sending a crew to orbit and study it for the first time in over 50 years.
articles.personality_title_fr: La fusée Artemis II de la NASA arrive sur le pas de tir pour le premier voyage habité vers la Lune en 50 ans
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La NASA prépare Artemis II, la première mission avec des astronautes en orbite autour de la Lune depuis 1972. Cette mission teste de nouvelles technologies et prépare les futurs alunissages.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – La grande fusée Space Launch System a été déplacée lentement sur 6,5 km jusqu’à son pas de tir au Kennedy Space Center en Floride. Ce trajet a duré presque 12 heures. Maintenant, la NASA va effectuer les derniers tests et une répétition générale avant un lancement prévu au plus tôt le 6 février 2024. Quatre astronautes, dont trois de la NASA et un Canadien, voleront autour de la Lune sans se poser.

**Impact** – Artemis II enverra des humains plus loin dans l’espace qu’auparavant. L’équipage orbitera autour de la face cachée de la Lune, étudiera sa surface et préparera Artemis III, qui vise à poser des astronautes au pôle sud lunaire. L’Agence spatiale européenne a contribué à construire une partie essentielle du vaisseau qui fournira énergie, propulsion et support de vie.

**Prochaine étape** – Après les tests et la répétition, la NASA fixera la date exacte de lancement. La mission Artemis II durera environ 10 jours, avec deux jours en orbite terrestre avant d’aller vers la Lune. Pendant ce temps, les ingénieurs construisent des modules pour les futures missions qui ramèneront des humains sur la surface lunaire.

**En une phrase** – La mission Artemis II de la NASA est une étape majeure pour ramener des astronautes sur la Lune en envoyant en toute sécurité un équipage en orbite autour de celle-ci pour la première fois depuis plus de 50 ans.
articles.personality_title_es: El cohete Artemis II de la NASA llega a la plataforma de lanzamiento para el primer viaje tripulado a la Luna en 50 años
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La NASA se prepara para Artemis II, la primera misión con astronautas en orbitar la Luna desde 1972. Esta misión probará nueva tecnología y preparará futuros aterrizajes lunares.

**Qué pasó** – El enorme cohete Space Launch System fue trasladado lentamente 6.5 kilómetros hasta su plataforma de lanzamiento en el Centro Espacial Kennedy en Florida. Este viaje duró casi 12 horas. Ahora, la NASA realizará pruebas finales y un ensayo general antes del lanzamiento previsto para el 6 de febrero de 2024 o poco después. Cuatro astronautas, tres de NASA y uno canadiense, volarán alrededor de la Luna pero no aterrizarán.

**Impacto** – Artemis II llevará humanos más lejos en el espacio que nunca antes. La tripulación orbitará el lado oculto de la Luna, estudiará su superficie y preparará Artemis III, que planea llevar astronautas al polo sur lunar. La Agencia Espacial Europea ayudó a construir una parte clave de la nave que proporcionará energía, propulsión y soporte vital.

**Próximo paso** – Tras las pruebas y el ensayo, la NASA decidirá la fecha exacta de lanzamiento. La misión Artemis II durará unos 10 días, incluyendo dos días orbitando la Tierra antes de dirigirse a la Luna. Mientras tanto, los ingenieros continúan construyendo módulos para futuras misiones que traerán humanos de regreso a la superficie lunar.

**Una frase clave** – La misión Artemis II de la NASA marca un paso importante para regresar astronautas a la Luna al enviar de forma segura una tripulación para orbitarla y estudiarla por primera vez en más de 50 años.
articles.image_prompt: A towering, stylized rocket silhouette gently illuminated by warm golden light stands poised on a simplified launch pad against a soft gradient sky, with four glowing stars arranged above symbolizing the Artemis II crew, while a large, softly glowing crescent Moon looms serenely in the background, evoking the mission’s journey beyond Earth.
